question: Which is denser: oceanic crust or continental crust?

content.source_1: Most oceanic crust produced at mid-ocean ridges has a fairly uniform thickness of about 6–7 km across the global seafloor.
content.source_2: Continental crust commonly ranges from roughly 30 to 70 km thick, with a global average near 35–40 km beneath stable regions.
content.source_3: The average elevation contrast (continents ~0.8 km above sea level vs. ocean basins ~4 km below) reflects isostatic balance in which continents are supported by thick, buoyant crust compared with the relatively thin crust beneath oceans.
content.source_4: Large oceanic plateaus (e.g., the Ontong Java and Caribbean Plateaus) are composed of anomalously thick oceanic crust, locally reaching 30–40 km thickness—several times normal oceanic values.
content.source_5: In highly extended rifts and passive margins, continental crust can be thinned to less than 25 km, in places approaching ~20 km immediately prior to seafloor spreading.
content.source_6: Hotspot magmatism can substantially thicken oceanic crust by adding massive basaltic sequences, building swells and plateaus that are much thicker than typical ridge-generated oceanic crust.

answer: more dense than the continental crust.
